resource.name: Richmond Community Survey
resource.description:
The City of Richmond enrolled in the National Research Center’s (NRC) National Citizen Survey (NCS) program in 2007. The City conducts a survey every two years.

Note: From 8/3/2020 to 2/1/2021, the 2019 data for the Richmond Community Survey was incorrectly utilizing unweighted data instead of weighted data. This error has now been resolved.

resource.name: Greenhouse Gas Emissions
resource.description:
Industrial data for 2015 to 2019 is not currently available to the City due to California regulations. In 2005 and 2012, commercial and industrial emissions were provided combined.

This dataset does not include emissions from BAAQMD Monitored Point Source emissions and AB 32 regulated sources in Richmond for 2015, 2017, 2018, and 2019. 

Solid waste data for 2018 and 2019 is pending additional data, but the majority of the data (approximately 80-90%) is included.

Emissions for water, which makes up a very small percent of overall emissions has currently been calculated for only 2005 and 2012 inventories.

BART data, a sub-category that makes up a small percentage of the transportation emissions has been collected only for the years 2015, 2017, 2018, and 2019.

The 2005 and 2012 inventories were conducted by the City and data was included in the City's Climate Action Plan. The 2015, 2017, 2018, and 2019 inventories were conducted using a tool created for the City through East Bay Energy Watch.
columns_description: Metric Tons of Carbon Dioxide Equivalent (MTCO2e)

resource.name: Richmond Police Department - Firearm Discharge Incidents
resource.description:
Officers are authorized to use deadly force to protect themselves or the public when facing an imminent threat of death or serious bodily injury. This dataset shows incidents where police officers discharged (fired) their firearm. 

Only incidents with Access Levels 3 and 5 are general access and approved for the public (other incidents are confidential and have limited access for Internal Affairs only).
columns_description: Whether the target involved an animal
Whether the target involved an animal that was killed
Whether the target involved an animal that was injured
Number of shots fired that hit the target
Whether there was injury, and who caused it
Number of shots fired by the citizen(s)
Number of shots fired that missed the target
Number of shots fired by the officer(s)
Whether the firearm discharge was intentional

resource.name: 2019 Achieve Summer Camp Literacy Gains Data
resource.description: Literacy gains are based on the San Diego Quick Assessment, which assesses the reading grade level of students. Students are given sets of words to read, with each set based on a reading grade level. The score corresponds to the reading grade level at which the student makes 1 or less mistake (Independent); 2 mistakes (Instructional); or 3 or more mistakes (Frustration).
columns_description: Independent Score is the reading grade level at which the student makes 1 error or less. Kindergarten = 0 and Pre-k = -1
Instructional Score is the reading grade level at which the student makes 2 errors. Kindergarten = 0 and Pre-k = -1
Frustration score is the reading grade level at which the student makes 3 errors or more. Kindergarten = 0 and Pre-k = -1
Independent Score is the reading grade level at which the student makes 1 error or less. Kindergarten = 0 and Pre-k = -1
Instructional Score is the reading grade level at which the student makes 2 errors. Kindergarten = 0 and Pre-k = -1
Frustration score is the reading grade level at which the student makes 3 errors or more. Kindergarten = 0 and Pre-k = -1

resource.name: Richmond Police Department - Police Pursuits
resource.description:
Officers engaged in police pursuits must continually balance the safety of the public and themselves against law enforcement's duty to apprehend law violators. Officers must discontinue a pursuit whenever circumstances indicate that continuation of the pursuit would be unsafe or when life or property is endangered.

This dataset shows vehicle pursuit data provided to the California Highway Patrol.
columns_description: Violation reason for engaging in a pursuit
Whether there was a DUI arrest
Type of damage from the accident
Type of injury from the accident
Total cost of damage to police vehicles
Total cost of damage to other parked vehicles
Total cost of damage to other property
Total cost of damage to suspect vehicles
Whether there was a helicopter available to assist
Whether there was aircraft available to assist
Whether a stop device was used
Total time of the pursuit in minutes
Which Richmond Police Department team/group was involved in the pursuit
Number of officers involved/associated with the pursuit

resource.name: California Small Business Covid-19 Relief Grant Program - Richmond Data
resource.description: This dataset is publicly available on and was downloaded directly from CA GO-Biz at https://business.ca.gov/coronavirus-2019/. This data includes all California Small Business Covid-19 Relief Grant Program awardees as of 5-13-2021 that applied in Contra Costa County with the Business City as Richmond, Point Richmond, or Hilltop and various spellings of the three aforementioned names. This data has been cleaned to change the "Business City" for businesses who applied with "Point Richmond" or "Hilltop" or various misspellings to "Richmond".
resource.attribution: CA Governor’s Office of Business and Economic Development (GO-Biz)

resource.name: CalEnviroScreen4.0SHP
resource.description: In October, 2021, the Office of Environmental Health Hazard Assessment (OEHHA), on behalf of the California Environmental Protection Agency (CalEPA), released Version 4.0 of the California Communities Environmental Health Screening Tool (CalEnviroScreen). CalEnviroScreen identifies California communities by census tract that are disproportionately burdened by, and vulnerable to, multiple sources of pollution.
